title: Rotherbaum
text:
Rotherbaum () is a quarter of <a href="Eimsb%C3%BCttel">Eimsbüttel</a>, a borough of <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. In 2020 the population was 17,114.
In <a href="German%20language">German</a>, "roter Baum" means "red tree". The "th", which in general was abolished in the spelling reform of 1900, was preserved in names. Depending on grammatical context, it might also be spelled with "n" as "Rothenbaum".
History.
Since 1800, distinguished and rich Hamburg citizens built the mansions at the bank of the <a href="Au%C3%9Fenalster">Außenalster</a> lake, to move from the city to a better surrounding area. An example is the building at Alsterufer street #27, built by <a href="Martin%20Haller">Martin Haller</a>—the architect of the <a href="Hamburg%20Rathaus">Hamburg Rathaus</a>—the building was later owned by Anton Riedemann, the founder of "Deutsch-Amerikanischen Petroleum-Gesellschaft"; later <a href="Esso">Esso</a>. As of 2009 the <a href="Consulate%20General%20of%20the%20United%20States%20in%20Hamburg">Consulate General of the United States in Hamburg</a> used the building.
From 1946 to 1948, <a href="War%20crimes%20of%20the%20Wehrmacht">war crime</a> trials were held by the <a href="British%20Armed%20Forces">British Armed Forces</a> in the "Curiohaus", an office building which is named after Johann Carl Daniel Curio. Located in Rotherbaum's "<a href="Rothenbaumchaussee">Rothenbaumchaussee</a> 15", it survived the <a href="bombing%20of%20Hamburg">bombing of Hamburg</a>. Among others, subject of the "Curiohaus processes" were <a href="Fritz%20Knoechlein">Fritz Knoechlein</a> for the <a href="Le%20Paradis%20massacre">Le Paradis massacre</a>, the SS-physician <a href="Alfred%20Trzebinski">Alfred Trzebinski</a> from the <a href="Neuengamme%20concentration%20camp">Neuengamme concentration camp</a>, Hamburg's famous <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player <a href="Otto%20Harder">Otto Harder</a> (sentenced to 15 years imprisonment) and the company "<a href="Tesch%20%26amp%3B%20Stabenow">Tesch & Stabenow</a>" which sold <a href="Zyklon%20B">Zyklon B</a>.
Geography.
In 2006, according to the statistical office of Hamburg and Schleswig-Holstein, Rotherbaum had a total area of 2.9 km². To the North the quarter <a href="Harvestehude">Harvestehude</a> is located. The southern boundaries of Rotherbaum to the quarters <a href="Neustadt%2C%20Hamburg">Neustadt</a>, <a href="St.%20Pauli">St. Pauli</a> and <a href="Sternschanze">Sternschanze</a> are formed by the railway tracks of the <a href="Hamburg%20S-Bahn">city train</a>. In the West the quarter <a href="Eimsb%C3%BCttel%20%28quarter%29">Eimsbüttel</a> can be found. In the East the lake <a href="Au%C3%9Fenalster">Außenalster</a> marks the boundaries to the quarter of <a href="St.%20Georg%2C%20Hamburg">St. Georg</a>.
Demographics.
In 2006, 16,853 inhabitants were living in Rotherbaum. The population density was . 11.3% were children under the age of 18, and 13.7% were 65 years of age or older. 22.6% were immigrants. 503 people were registered as unemployed and 4,866 were employees subject to <a href="social%20insurance">social insurance</a> contributions.
In 1999 there were 11,615 households, out of which 11.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them and 63.3% of all households were made up of individuals. The average household size was 1.57.
In 2006 there were 3,299 criminal offences (192 crimes per 1000 people).
Education.
The campuses of the <a href="University%20of%20Hamburg">University of Hamburg</a> and the <a href="Hochschule%20f%C3%BCr%20Musik%20und%20Theater%20Hamburg">University of Music and Drama of Hamburg</a> are located in Rotherbaum. In 2006 there were also one elementary school, the Grundschule Turmweg, and one secondary school, the Sophie-Barat-Schule. The Talmud Tora Schule, which was established in 1805, closed in 1942, and re-opened in 2002, is located in Rotherbaum. <a href="Wilhelm-Gymnasium%20%28Hamburg%29">Wilhelm-Gymnasium</a> was located in Rotherbaum from 1885 to 1945.
Culture.
Sports.
The main tennis court of the (former German Open) <a href="Hamburg%20Masters">Hamburg Masters</a> tournament is located in the "<a href="Am%20Rothenbaum">Am Rothenbaum</a>" stadium. Though it is named after the Rotherbaum area, it is officially located in the neighbouring <a href="Harvestehude">Harvestehude</a> quarter.
The hockey club, <a href="Club%20an%20der%20Alster">Club an der Alster</a>, has facilities in Rotherbaum.
<a href="Sportplatz%20at%20Rothenbaum">Sportplatz at Rothenbaum</a>, which was opened in 1910, was the stadium used by <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> and later by their amateur team and for promotion play-offs at the end of each season, until the stadium was demolished in 1994.
Infrastructure.
Directly at the artificial <a href="Au%C3%9Fenalster">Außenalster</a> lake is the <a href="Consulate%20General%20of%20the%20United%20States%20in%20Hamburg">Consulate General of the United States</a>.
Health systems.
In Rotherbaum were 16 day-care centers for children, 142 physicians in private practice and 9 pharmacies.
Transportation.
Rotherbaum is serviced by the <a href="rapid%20transit">rapid transit</a> system of the <a href="Hamburg%20S-Bahn">city train</a> with the stations <a href="Hamburg%20Dammtor%20railway%20station">Hamburg Dammtor</a>, located in the <a href="Dammtor">homonymous place</a>. Long distance trains also stop at this station. The <a href="Hamburg%20U-Bahn">Hamburg U-Bahn</a> service the Hallerstraße station.
According to the Department of Motor Vehicles (Kraftfahrt-Bundesamt), in the quarter Rotherbaum were 5,446 private cars registered (324 cars/1000 people). There were 201 traffic accidents total, including 173 traffic accidents with damage to persons.
